 Well, what you are doing here is trying to cop out by changing the rules of the game. The game rule says that X or Y are your only options. For whatever reason (doesn't matter), it is impossible to silence the child without lethal means, and it is impossible for you to draw the pursuers away by any means within your power.
 
 The reason the rules of the game are drawn so tightly is to force you into making a moral choice which has inevitable consequences, in order to explore how people actually handle morality. You either kill the baby, or by doing nothing, you enable (as opposed to cause) the deaths of several other innocents. By definition, there is no other choice here. The question is: is it better for one to die so that many can live? And under what circumstances would you be prepared to take an innocent life in order to save others?
 
 True, in real life, the choices MIGHT not be as stark, but this is a thought experiment designed to reveal how we think morally, by stripping away all extraneous considerations. It's not an issue of what action is right or wrong in absolute terms, but what anyone feels is right or wrong in that context.
 
 I'd risk offing the child by muffling its cries to the point they could not be heard, and if that inevitably meant it couldn't breathe, well, too bad. The situation is presumably not the fault of any of those hiding, and if everyone is caught, the child dies along with everyone else, anyway. Still, lots of people will baulk at actually performing such an act, even though they might, under slightly different circumstances, choose to allow the child to die, so long as they weren't the agent of death.

 I think you are missing the point of the game, which is to try and unlock the mechanics of actual moral thinking by stripping away complications to simplify a situation. It's a common method used by scientists interested in studying the evolution of morality -- it's an attempt to strip the system down to its simplest parts. It's the application of scientific reductionism to a behavioural question.
 
 Of course real life is more complex, but what scientists are trying to get at with these artificial scenarios is a glimpse of how humans think, without the hindrance of a subjective justification of their thinking. Reductionism has a successful record in science, because it aims to fix all the variables but the ones that interest the researcher.
